Business Requirements document.ChecklistItem: Document has a clear title, version, author, and date.
Includes a document control and revision history section.
Document purpose and audience are clearly stated.
References related documents (e.g., project charter,  specs).
Business drivers and context are explained.
Benefits and expected outcomes are described.
Stakeholders, roles, and responsibilities are identified.
Stakeholder needs and expectations are captured.
In-scope processes, systems, and functions are clearly listed.
Out-of-scope items are explicitly stated.
Scope aligns with project charter or business case.
Each requirement is uniquely identified and clearly written.
Requirements are SMART (Specific, Measurable, Achievable, Relevant, Time-bound).
Requirements are categorized (e.g., functional, non-functional, reporting).
Business rules and logic are clearly documented.
As-Is and To-Be states are clearly described
Requirements are written in business-friendly language.
All relevant assumptions are listed and validated.
Constraints (e.g., time, resources, system limitations) are documented.
Dependencies on systems, processes, or teams are identified.
Interfaces and integration points are described.
Compliance with regulatory or industry standards is considered.
Clear acceptance criteria are provided for each requirement.
Requirements are mapped to source documents or business goals.
List of Open and Closed points to be documented properly.
Reviewed by all relevant stakeholders.
Final version is approved and signed off.

Configuration Document.ChecklistItem: Document includes title, version, author, and date.
Revision history is maintained and accurate.
Purpose and scope of the document are clearly defined.
References related documents (e.g., BRD, FDS, test cases).
System (ERP) and specific module(s) are clearly identified.
Configuration environment (DEV, QA, PROD) is specified.
Configuration steps are described in detail.
Screen paths (menu navigation) and transaction codes are provided.
Field-level settings and values are clearly defined.
Custom settings vs. standard settings are distinguished.
Screenshots are included for clarity and verification.
Configuration supports defined business processes.
Any changes to standard process flow are explained.
Configuration decisions are justified with business rationale.
Master and transactional data dependencies are described.
Default values and mandatory fields are specified.
User roles impacted by configuration are listed.
Access controls for configuration settings are described.
Dependencies on other modules or systems are identified.
Potential downstream impacts are assessed.
Compliance with organizational and vendor standards is confirmed.
Document is peer-reviewed for accuracy and completeness.
Comments from reviewers are addressed.
Final version is approved and signed off.

Functional Design Document.ChecklistItem: Document has a clear title, version number
Correct Functional Design template is used
Includes a revision history with changes, Authors, approvers and dates
States the objective and scope of the custom development.
Lists related documents (e.g., BRD, Technical Specs, Process Flows).
All business requirements are clearly stated or referenced.
Functional design aligns with the approved business requirements.
Assumptions and constraints are clearly stated.
Process flows or diagrams are included and accurate.
Clearly defines input, process logic, and output.
All custom logic is documented with decision criteria of the business logic.
Lists down all the names of custom objects created like Process names, lookup, profile options etc
Lists down , describes exceptions and error handling scenarios
Process steps are traceable to business requirements

Report layout and content requirements are documented.
Filters, sorting, and grouping logic are defined.
The report field descriptions and derivation logic clearly documented
Output formats (PDF, Excel, etc.) are specified.
Master and transactional data requirements are identified and clearly documented
Source and target systems are documented along with the middleware details as applicable
Data mappings and transformation logic are included.
Integration points (APIs, middleware, interfaces) are specified
Required user roles and access levels are defined.
Sensitive data handling and visibility are addressed.
Complies with organizational security policies.
Includes functional acceptance criteria.
Lists test scenarios or test conditions for UAT.
Describes expected results for major use cases.
Identifies impact on existing processes or modules.
Lists dependencies on other customizations or systems.
Flags any obsolete or replaced functionality.
Follows ERP vendor’s development guidelines (e.g., SAP, Oracle).
Naming conventions, code structures, and documentation are standardized.
Adheres to internal governance and change management policies.
Document is peer-reviewed for accuracy and completeness.
Comments from reviewers are addressed.
Final version is approved and signed off.

Test Scripts.ChecklistItem: Test script includes unique ID, title, version, and author.
Clearly states the module, process area, and functionality under test.
Document includes preparer, reviewer, and approver sections.
Test script is traceable to related business requirement or user story.
Test objective and purpose are clearly defined.
Preconditions (prerequisites, setup conditions) are documented.
Test data required for execution is specified.
Step-by-step instructions are clear, numbered, and logical.
Expected results are defined for each step.
Pass/fail criteria are objective and measurable.
Includes postconditions (e.g., data cleanup, next steps).
Covers all relevant business scenarios (positive and negative).
Includes test cases for exceptions and boundary conditions.
All functional requirements are mapped to at least one test case.
Validates integrations and data flow where applicable.
Includes relevant workflow or approval processes.
Uses business terminology that end users understand.
Avoids ambiguous or overly technical language.
Includes relevant screenshots, forms, or references. Screenshot is mandatory for every test result
Formatting is consistent and readable (e.g., tables, bolding, bullets).
Test data is realistic and representative of production scenarios.
Environment (DEV, QA, UAT) required for testing is specified.
Dependencies on other systems or modules are clearly stated.
User roles and permissions for test execution are defined.
Instructions for logging defects are included.
Each test step provides traceability to test results or defect IDs.
Retesting or regression steps are documented if applicable.
Reviewed by both functional and technical stakeholders.
Peer-reviewed for completeness and accuracy.
Final script is approved and signed off for use in UAT or SIT.
